Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 12:32PM HelenaJ wrote: Hey Shelzie, It is indeed different when it is yourself going through it.  And it is a really tough time now not knowing your course of treatment and the swirling of thoughts in your brain.  A severe form of torture that only we can know about.  Once treatment gets on its way you do manage to get a grip a bit more, possibly because like the ladies above have already mentioned, you can get a bit more in control plus you can focus on moving forward instead of  staying in limbo. For me I madly searched the internet, that is how I found this place, but I know if is full of doom and gloom as well.  Talking to my younger sister, who was diagnosed at 35, 10 years ago, was very calming for me, just talking to someone who understands and have some insight into the fears was, for me, very helpful. Hope you are getting some sleep, the best soother possible. big hugs Helena
Posts.Title: Needing some encouragement... Shelzie65 CharlestonGirl

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2009 11:29PM HelenaJ wrote: deep breath...and again Emme, first so sorry you are having to come here ...but this place is one in a million..you will be safe and looked after here.   I didn't do chemo but just wanted to let you know that I am usually one of the few around at this time (I'm in Australia and it is 6.24pm) most of the American ladies are sleeping and will get back to you soon - weekends are quiet as well.  I didn't do chemo honey (I'm 47) but my beautiful sister did when she was 35 and is wonderfully happy and healthy at 45 now.  Moving quick is great - like you said it is to be grateful for, getting a treatment plan is good, moving forward is good, stay busy..it is when it gets quiet that the mind can go crazy. Sending you big hugs from Australia to keep you warm and to let you know I care. big hugs Helena

Posts.Title: May I wait here? Melinda41 BarbAnne41

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 06:47PM HelenaJ wrote: LindaSue, I had 6 weeks off work - you are doing fantastic.  It is also just going back to a routine you could do standing on your head b4 surgery.  Things are still healing and emotionally and mentally things are working in overdrive.  That in itself will exhaust you.  I think we all get by with a lot of adrenalin for awhile but the body has been through a huge operation, not to mention the amount of drugs they pump into us for the general anaesthetic and recovery. I have just had my exchange surgery (only 1.5 hours) and it seemed to knock me around more than the bilat mastectomy.  Energy levels vary drastically during the day - I'm a runner and to be zapped like this is horrible - I totally understand, but I also realise that to get the best result from all these surgeries we have to relax.  I napped today and here I am up at 2.44am and can't sleep!!!  Just my thoughts but I coped amazingly well through the bilat mast and immediate recon surgery, both physically and mentally, and I found a few months down the track I collapsed emotionally.  Perhaps I wasn't coping all that well on the inside.  I fooled myself I guess.  We need to really look after ourselves inside and out. soft hugs Helena
Posts.Title: Exhaustion Kaidog lumineaux

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 11:05PM HelenaJ wrote: Hey Debra - Hugs.  I know my story is a little different to yours but I can understand.  I had a bilat mastectomy with immediate reconstruction and now have my implants.  It has been a very difficult journey even with implants and I really think it has been largely my fault.  My DH doesn't go anywhere near the "new foobs" and we didn't have any sex at all during my expansion process.  Boobs are such a big deal sexually for both men and women.  Once all my surgeries are finished I am going to buy some sexy lingerie (which I used to do when we first met) and see if that helps - if it helps me I'm sure it will help my DH. The anticipation is worse than the fact and we left it for so long that I almost felt embarrassed.  It feels so good to be so close to another human being.  I did mention once on another thread that it is a bit like child birth - your DH sees "the war zone" down there and it takes a while for them to rid that picture from their mind.  Time... time ...time. And yes, this forum is amazing and has meant so much to me through all this crappy BC stuff. big hugs Helena

Posts.Title: Update andPrayers for Kbugmom hollyann sheila888

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2009 12:15PM HelenaJ wrote: Hi dualgate, I was 46 and similar diagnoses to you (see my signature below) - I too questioned the need for chemo that my oncologist was recommending.  I am assuming that your nodes were clear???  Anyway I went over the 12 week mark which over here in Australia they prefer to have chemo started as I had to wait on the oncotype results from America.  As you can see I came back as a 6 - 5% chance of recurrence over 5 years - chemo wouldn't have added any benefit to that statistic.  I am now on Tamoxifen for 5 years and doing extremely well with no side fx (been on it for 10 months).  I was diagnosed in October 2008 and didn't get my Oncotpye results till early March 2009 - I had a bilateral mastectomy in between all that though. Personally once you get the oncotype results back I think that overrides the need for a 2nd opinion.  Oncoptyping is held in quite high regard now.  The problem lies of course if you fall within the intermediate range where the pros and cons of chemo is still uncertain - I am assuming this is why you have joined the clinical trial (is it tailorX??). There is no way of knowing or guessing what your oncotype result will be as the results are so individual - same diagnosis can produce varying oncotype scores.  You don't have long to wait now though.  I have my fingers crossed that you have a low score and you can forget all about chemo and a 2nd opinion. Let us know  how you get on. big hugs Helena
Posts.Title: need some advise, Oncotype DX dualgate one-L

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2009 09:28AM HelenaJ wrote: Hi Irishred, l breastfed both my children and have breast cancer.  There is no rhyme or reason to this disease - none that we know of at the moment anyway.  Like Deirdre1 said "you didn't do this to yourself".  It just sux pure and simple.  I think it is different for every single woman, genetics, environment, stress, blah blah blah. I do know though that bad things happen to good people. hope you have a good weekend soft hugs Helena
Posts.Title: Just a Weird Though Irishred PanamaBound

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2009 02:09PM HelenaJ wrote: 13 is a good score dualgate, officially listed as "low risk" - many women on that result and more have opted for no chemo.  All the best with the trial (and like you said you don't have to participate). Merry Xmas and yes, relax and enjoy.  xx
Posts.Title: need some advise, Oncotype DX dualgate one-L

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 07:40PM HelenaJ wrote: I don't have much to add except sometimes docs get it wrong.  When I was face-to-face told I had breast cancer all I could think of was "chemo".  My sister had to be hospitalised for the entire time for hers, it nearly killed her, literally.  Anyway of course I asked my doctor "do I need chemo" and she said "yes".   Well I didn't.  Sometimes they get it wrong, sometimes they assume.  My biopsy was inconclusive and it was only after my pathology report following my lumpectomy that I knew what I was dealing with, but then I am in Australia .... very far behind the eight ball here. Good luck with your results on Monday Sea, the waiting is a nightmare. soft hugs Helena
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2009 12:30AM - edited Oct 3, 2009 12:30AM by HelenaJ Cath honey, So sorry you have to be here.  My sister was diagnosed at 35 with stage 3 IDC - she is now 10 years NED (no evidence of disease) and a single mom of a 13 year old daughter - her daugher was 3 when she was diagnosed.  There is a future, there is hope.  You ARE in shock.  The first few months are a nightmare but once you get some more information then you can put in place a treatment plan and get some control back.  Things will move pretty quickly and keep you busy.  It might help to get something from your doctor to help you sleep during this tough time, sleep deprivation is so common and can really stuff you around.  And you know what ... this place is full of beautiful ladies, real life angels, who can help you through. I'm not advocating smoking or drinking (although I love my wine) but don't be too hard on yourself at the moment. Big big hugs Helena

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 05:00PM HelenaJ wrote: Reese - well an adenoma isn't ideal but it is benign thank god.  Not quite sure about a nuloma, did a search and it certainly didn't help much.  I'm so glad you are following this up Reese as scary as it must be.  I hope you are getting lots of love and support there, you have mine.  Let us know about your follow up MRI which I hope is soon.  I noticed you posted this on your thread, perhaps someone may know what a nuloma means. thinking of you and glad you are being looked after by your medical team. big hugs Helena
Posts.Title: Help Me Understand Please .. reesespcs28 HelenaJ

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 04:44AM HelenaJ wrote: Hi Sparrow, like Helena (how strange is that!!) said b4 the waiting is just horrible.  The mind can play tricks on us especially when you have no idea what is going on and what the future will hold.   Can you get your PCP to call and get a copy of the report perhaps she will have more "pull" with the breast imaging centre.  Worth a try. Reading up on the internet can be beneficial and helpful but can also fill you with dread and fear.  You don't know what you are dealing with yet so please try and stay calm and you can come here to get a cyber hug and empathy.  We have all been there and understand the turmoil you are going through now.  I'm not sure how to deal with your anxiety/panic attacks but you sound like you are doing the right thing seeing professionals and getting help. Try and have someone with you when you get your results and when you have your MRI - its useful to have a second pair of ears, regardless of whether the results are good or bad. sending you big hugs Helena
Posts.Title: I just can't deal with this Sparrow one-L

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 09:27PM HelenaJ wrote: Hey Suze, sorry to see you are here and unfortunately I do not have the answers to your questions however I did a lot of googling waiting for my results - and yes there is some very scary stuff out there but it also enabled me to have a better grip on what my surgeon and oncologist had to say and I had plenty of questions written down to ask - and I had plenty of sleepless nights to fill!!!  This site was an absolute saviour during that time.  There are so many different kinds of breast cancers and there isn't a one size fits all treatment regime.  I was told I needed chemo and thanx to Oncotype DX I didn't.  I saw a surgeon first as they need to remove the lump and hopefully get clear margins (I didn't).  They can also do a senitinal node biopsy.  Its usually from a lumpectomy that they get all the information they need to plan the road ahead and then you see an oncologist who will talk about chemo and/or hormone therapy plus more fun stuff. I had a very bad 12 months leading up to my diagnosis with hormones and thought I was heading into menopause.  Nope, heading into breast cancer.  I am almost 100% ER & PR positive so I'm sure it is linked.  And yes, there are many good outcomes here.  Although you are frightened, rightly so, you also sound very intelligent and switched on.  It is a bit of a no mans land at the moment but once you get the total picture you can plan a way forward which can give you something to focus on and feel like you are fighting this crappy disease. big hugs Helena
Posts.Title: Unfortunately New Suze35 lago

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 07:34AM HelenaJ wrote: Reese, sorry to hear of your continuing worries for someone so young.  (((Hugs))).  I would certainly try another specialist - there is definitely something there if you felt it and they should be able to tell you what it is or at least investigate it further.  Many women have written about "a feeling" they have so never underestimate your own instinct.  I'm not saying it is something to be concerned about but you need to find out what you are dealing with.  Don't be afraid to seek another opinion, this is your health and your life, it is important. Please let us know how you get on.  Thinking of you. soft hugs Helena
Posts.Title: Help Me Understand Please .. reesespcs28 HelenaJ

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2010 02:00AM HelenaJ wrote: Willingtowonder - I had isolated tumor cells in two of my nodes, officially node negative and I was able to do the oncotype test and it came back with a 6 - I didn't do chemo.  I too am almost 100% ER & PR positive.  As Deanna mentioned Oncotype has now accepted testing for 1 or 2 nodes positive.  3 is exceedingly low as, even with my score of 6, chemo would have provided no further benefit than tamoxifen on it own.  Maybe your grade 3 is what your Onc may be concerned about.  I also did the CYP2D6 test to see if I could metabolise tamoxifen and I am an Extensive Metaboliser - which settles my fears, especially since I have no side fx??!!!!  To be honest I just had to read as much as I could, ask lots of questions (like you are doing), then sit myself down and decide upon a way forward which I could live with.  I trust Oncotype DX and although I am a born worrier I feel I have made the right decision. Quality of life going forward means not just trying to beat this damn disease but having courage in your convinction in whatever path you choose. This is a horrible time, I remember it so vividly and I wish you all the best in your decision making. big hugs Helena
Posts.Title: chemo or just tamoxefen willingtowonder dlb823

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2008 08:44PM HelenaJ wrote: Hi everyone - at 46 I have decided to have a bilateral mastectomy and immediate reconstruction after lumpectomy showed extensive papillary DCIS in left breast and 13mm invasive lump (not sure what grade) - will have a sentinal node biopsy done at time of mastectomy.  My younger sister was diagnosed at 35 so have a family history.  Mum mum died in a car accident when I was 10 and I miss her so much - I don't want my two girls (aged 9 and 6) to have to cope with that if I can help it!!!!  Can anyone please tell me whether I should agree to chemo after the mastectomy if my nodes are clear.  Is is necessary?  Wish I wasn't here but glad for all this wonderful support.
